comments.commentBody: I think the key is turning their anger toward the government into anger toward the 1%. Because the government is part of the 1%. And the true beneficiaries of government entitlements is the top 0.01%.

The wealthy make the laws -- that seems to be the key -- but they do so by also controlling the public "debate".

The widespread confusion that supports the upside-down logic and political behavior of the 99%, documented by Professor K., is deliberately induced by the media and political organs controlled by and working on behalf of the wealthy. The Koch Brothers are a salient example -- they almost single-handedly financed the Tea Party in the last congressional election, or at least seeded it generously.

How to break this cycle? Only one way to even hope -- get money out of politics. Unfortunately, it;s the bought-and-paid-for politicians that would have to do the getting-out, and that's not likely without lots of pressure from the street and, ultimately, from the voters.

"... composed of wealthy, mostly Mormon farmers who dominate the legislature and make the laws."

What? Wealthy people make the laws? I'm shocked - shocked I tell you!

It almost makes you think that the wealthy people know that paying low wages not only saves them money, but helps engender an animus towards Washington.

I live in Idaho which proudly calls itself the "reddest, whitest state in the union" and after looking at the map of government payments, excluding farm subsidies, it makes sense. The population/political majority lives in the southern region which is composed of wealthy, mostly Mormon farmers who dominate the legislature and make the laws.

Further north where the government subsidies are in excess of 25% and the jobs are mostly geared toward natural resource exploitation, the population is shall we say, educationally disadvantaged, to the point that they believe the govermnent is the reason they are unemployed-- too much regulation on mining, logging, pollution etc. Therefore it is very easy to get them on the side of those who say "get your government hands off my Medicare". Simply put it's called ignorant.

Don't forget the role of the race card in all of this. People fundamentally want to look down on someone else. If they can be convinced that "those people" are the ones using government benefits, then that is enough for them to be excited by someone like Newt Gingrich telling them they should support a shrinking role of government. They clearly forget how much government benefits were helping them directly.

That geo-map showed something else interesting to me -- the states with the highest concentrations of Hispanics like California, Arizona, Nevada, also had the lowest amount of government benefits flowing to them. This is largely because the Hispanic population is very young and has a very small population over age 65, the age range where use of the most expensive government benefits occur. Anyway, whenever the topic of Hispanics and government benefits comes up, many in general population go into fits thinking about any government benefit that might be consumed by a child of Hispanic descent. Really they shouldn't look farther than their own selves as the largest consumers of government benefits.

Liberals originally called them entitlements because people were entitled to what they received based on what they paid in, just as you described.  Now, however, most liberals are quite careful to not call any program an entitlement because the right-wing has successfully managed to turn it into a dirty word, just like the word liberal.  Your post demonstrates the confusion they've managed to sow.

hmmm, except most social security recipients will take out what they've contributed to the fund in just a few years (the figure I've heard is three); after that, it's welfare.

Not saying that I think we should do away with social security, but we should stop pretending that it's not an entitlement program, too.

The first Social Security recipients paid in nothing. FDR sold Social Security to the public as an entitlement, getting out what you paid in, but it was really an effort to redistribute income at the time so that people, particularly the impoverished elderly, would not starve in the streets. He would not let that happen, and thought we were, at heart, as a people, better than that. Unfortunately, it appears he was wrong.

Dr. Mettler asked the wrong question; in the view of the people she asked, Social Security Insurance and Unemployment Insurance and Medicare insurance are, in fact, insurance programs into which they have paid their entire lives precisely in order to have the money available later, and not 'government programs' like entitlements or welfare. There's a fundamental moral difference. Why is this so hard for people to understand?

FDR understood this and that's what it's called 'insurance'. When Krugman calls these things entitlements, he is participating in weakening them by reducing their support.

I am a Liberal too, but I can't support entitlement programs. I can tolerate public insurance. Once it becomes an entitlement, my employer is relieved of all responsibility, from a moral point of view. Charity is not their business. We have a progressive tax system already, and they gave at the office.

Please don't say entitlements. Good people depend on these programs. Will you be happy with people calling you a moocher or a moral cripple when you are old and collecting Social Security?

-Holmes

I had thought that working-class conservative resentment of government programs was simple psychology. The powerless tend to resent power, especially if that power makes you stand in line, fill out forms, and feel less than the special human being you know yourself to be.

But the statistics you quote suggest otherwise: that 40% of avowed aid recipients are unaware of the facts of their personal economy suggests that this group may in fact be narcotized. Is that why Florida drug tests welfare recipients? To see who needs another dose?

Their Red-state overlords, however, have no such excuse. What could their goals be? I suspect that, beyond their personal feudal fantasies, they have none.

I think that race has been insufficiently discussed in attempting to explain how some people can both despise government benefits and accept them with so little discomfort.  I wish I could peer into their minds when they say the words "government" and "welfare."   I'd be shocked if they're visualizing someone with white skin.  And when they hear the words  "Medicare" and "Social Security" I'd bet they're not imagining people with dark complexions.  To generalize:  government transfers that primarily benefit white people are worthwhile; programs perceived to benefit people who are not white are unworthy and wasteful in the minds of many government-haters.  I don't think we can have a productive conversation about taxes and government spending until we put the issue of race on the table.  It's not the only issue, but it's a critical one.
